utterances: A little sound effect there from the car's unveiling.
The Volt is a plug-in electric car that GM says would go 40 miles on the first charge before a gasoline engine kicks in to recharge the battery as you drive.
They're estimating it might be available in 2010.
GM also won the two biggest awards at the show: Car of the Year for the Saturn Aura, and Truck of the Year for the Chevy Silverado.
All the glitz from the auto show, though, is not enough to glaze over big questions about GM's future.
The company lost more than $10 billion in 2005, and is expected to post another big lost for '06.
Still when GM Chairman Rick Wagoner spoke to me from the international auto show today, he was quite upbeat.
We've actually increased the amount of capital spending on new projects - on new products over the last couple of years.
And fortunately, at the show, people are seeing the outcome of that commitment, even in tight financial times.
So today, for example, we showed the new Chevy Malibu and, I think, got a great reaction yesterday.
The new Cadillac CTS, we won the car and truck of the year.
That all says that, in the car-truck business, you've got to be willing to invest the money up front, and despite financial times being a little tough, we've stuck to our guns there.
The investments, I imagine, are quite difficult when you're saddled with these so called legacy costs, health and pension benefits for more than a million retirees and their dependents.
Other companies have abandoned their pension plans when they got to be too costly.
Is this something that you have considered and might you have to consider this in the future if you want to continue to make these kinds of investments?
All right, let's take a step back now and examine something else President Trump said yesterday after his meeting with the European Commission president.
Yeah it's - you know, it's the kind of thing that people not on the inside occasionally suggest.
It doesn't feel right to me.
I feel like we have a responsibility to the people that work with us.
We have a responsibility to our shareholders.
You know, total pension plan is in the range of $90 billion, and that's more than fully funded as a result of the commitment of those huge resources over the last 15 years.
And now, we're working on the health care obligations, which are very large and frankly formidable.
We've worked with our union.
We tried to reduce those somewhat, and we need to work some in that area.
But we think the right solution is to work our way through it not, if you will, toss in the towel.
Given some of these difficult issues that you're grappling with, there's a statement that you hear time and time again from the analysts who monitor the auto industry.
They say that GM's hands are essentially tied, that even if the company does everything perfectly right, even if the planets line up for you, that you're still cooked.
Tell why they're wrong.
Well, I, you know, to be honest, nobody foresaw 15 months ago that we would be able to take actions, many in conjunction with our union, to reduce our cost base in North America by $9 billion.
We need to do more of that, but I think it shows the kinds of things that when we need to make the big moves, we sit down and figure out how to do it and get it done.
Given the tough issues, was or will bankruptcy ever be an option?
It's not an option that I think is at all attractive for GM.
We're a consumer-based business.
People have the option to buy a lot of different cars and trucks.
And I think we'd have a devastating impact on our revenue if something like that were to be undertaken.
So we've explicitly said we don't believe that that's the right strategy for the company.
And, you know, again, if you'd look back 15 months ago versus today, I think, you know, even the harshest critic has to conclude that we have moved the needle dramatically.
We certainly have more work to do, but I think we're showing that we can fix this business the right way.
Some have made argument that what's bad for auto industry is bad for America.

It's - the auto industry has long been a driver of the American economy - and I guess you'll have to pardon pun there - but what, if any, role does the federal government in helping the auto industry survive this rough patch.

I would say that the policies of the government have tended to lean towards, a bias towards freer trade and open markets which we think on balance is a good idea, but in some ways ignores the fact that other countries do not allow their currencies to be priced by the market.
So give, for example, Japanese manufacturers significant competitive advantage by the systematic under valuation of the Yen would be an issue that we'd like to see our government more proactive on.
The health care cost crisis in the country - it hits us very hard.
We think there's a lot of areas where government leadership could help make sure their health care quality goes up while the cost goes down.
So there are certainly things that we look for even stronger leadership from Washington on, but, by the same token, we recognize a lot of these issues are ours to fix and we're fixing them.
I'd like to ask you about the new electric passenger vehicle, the Chevy Volt - a good-looking car.
After essentially pulling the plug on a previous project, the EV1, why did GM decide to invest in this car?
We think that the time is moving to be right.
The advancements in battery technology have moved at a good pace over the last decade or so.
So this issue of having a battery, which is capable of powering a vehicle for an appropriate range, for example, is - let me say more optimistic than what we had back 10 years ago.

And I think the good news is the work we did on the EV1, subsequent work on hybrid systems that we're bringing out even as we speak has given us a better knowledge base and come up with what is, we think, a very innovative, what we call E-Flex system, which is electrically-driven vehicles.

And then, we wrap the beautiful car, the Chevy Volt concept around that to demonstrate to people that we see a vision of an industry that can rely on a diverse source of energies and offer it up in a product that is exciting to consumers, and doesn't require consumers to make tradeoffs, other than being willing to have different forms of power that go under the vehicle other than just gasoline.
We should say that this is a car that that can use gasoline but also you can plug this in at night.

But as you know, Mr. Wagoner, skeptics will listen to your explanation and they're so going to say that this looks like a good PR move for the company in part to counter all the negative press GM received for ending the EV1.
And this is still a concept car with no definite deadline for production.
So I guess the question is, are you really, truly committed to developing this car?
Yeah.
You know, this stuff about - I really chuckle at someone who thinks that we would do a product like that to respond to criticism about stopping producing a car five or six years ago.
If someone's got that perspective that we should really think about what their motives are.
I can tell you, we bring this to the show because this is a breakthrough idea.
And when you add at it to the fact that we've got 12 hybrid models that we'll have in the market in '07 and '08, we're leading in biofuels, the application of ethanol.
This is a company that's serious about addressing the issue of the reliance of the industry on imported oil.
And I guess there's always going to be cynics out there, and, you know, what we can do is execute our plans and show people.
Mr.
Wagoner, thanks so much.
Thanks.
Nice to be with you.
That was Rick Wagoner, chairman of General Motors.
He spoke to us from the North American International Auto Show at the Cobo Center in Detroit, Michigan.
In California, a new kind of racial problem has surfaced at San Quentin prison.
A Jewish inmate there says his life is in danger because he's been classified as white and housed with neo-Nazis and other white supremacists who hate Jews.
As NPR's Phillip Martin reports, that's why the prisoner is asking a federal court to change his status from white to other.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Thank you.
It sounds wonderful.
Maybe.
It's all, all of that.
You know, when you're in a girl group there's always some kind of issues there.
She's singing too much.
People are always going to have their favorites.
Who they think is the prettiest, who they think can sing the best.
So all of that, you know, had something to do with the breakup.
You know, I'm out here in L.A.
and I didn't get a chance to see you guys.
But you performed in L.A.
on a big bill of favorites and I heard that you were just amazing.
So you obviously are friends enough to get together and sing together sometimes.
But I want to ask you back during the time when you were originally together, I understand that there were some issues about industry preferences about what people should look like.
Tell me what happened here.
Oh definitely.
When we first came into the industry, I was told that because there were two dark-skinned girls in the group, they didn't think that was like the epitome of a good girl group.
So, you know, it took us a little longer.
Well, it didn't take us that long but there was a little issue there with the two dark-skinned girls being in the group.
You know, but we got through it.
Does it make you angry or sad that we're still dealing with this kind of skin color issue today?
It makes me angry and sad.
You know, you can be light, dark, whatever, and still be beautiful.
You know, why do we have to dwell on a certain color?
You know, talent is talent, let's get past that.
So let's move forward from SWV.
So after the group you did a secular solo project that did well.
Now you've moved on to gospel.
Why did you make that choice?
This is something that I've always wanted to do from the beginning of SWV.
Before I started singing with the girls I was singing in a popular choir with Hezekiah Walker.
So, you know, I was always doing gospel.
I knew that one day that I would come back to it and the timing was just right.
You know, so everything fell into place for me to do this gospel record.
So I knew the time was now.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing) Ooh baby Lord, ooh baby Lord, like Shakaina(ph), glory, glory from on high.
You found me.
(Singing) You found me, Lord.
Lord -
(Singing) Now Jesus feels your spirit.
Tell me -
(Singing) And (unintelligible) meâ€¦
There are a lot of artists - we just recently talked to Kelly Rowland who put out a gospel single.
There are a lot of artists who have had a history in secular music that are crossing over into gospel or putting out, you know, songs, albums.
Why do you think that that's happening at this moment in time?
You know, we just need some more positive music out right now.
And I know for me I wanted to be part of that.
A lot of the, I guess, R and B music that's out right now, it's just really not talking about much.
And then, you know, people are just thankful and grateful for everything that God has done for them and that's doing for them.
And as for me, I'm still here so I'm just grateful for that.
Now you have an amazing SWV song, "I'm So Into You," that was just, it's just like so fun.
It really reminds me of a fun time and like, you know, and now you're married, you're a mother.
Do you ever look back on some of the things that you sang and say, oh gee, you know, that was the old me and this is the new me?
Or is your progression into gospel different on a different level?
Oh definitely.
There are things that I, you know, I've recorded in the past that I don't even sing now in my show.
You know, we don't do "Downtown," we don't do "Can We.
You know, there are songs that I won't sing anymore because that was the old me.
And, you know, things that I used to do, I don't even do them no more, so no need to sing about them.
Are you embarrassed by the old you?
Or you just say that was me then?
No. I'm not embarrassed by anything.
That's just a stepping-stone for me to get to where I am today.
What's been your favorite part of being a musician, whether it's with your gospel album, your secular solo album being with SWV.
What moment comes to mind for something that you just really felt was amazing?
